description.plain:
With a career spanning over twenty-five years, Usher Raymond has become one of the most influential voices in contemporary R&B. Having sold over 75 million records worldwide, also attaining nine number-one records on the Billboard 100 charts, he is one of the most accomplished R&B singers in the world.

Coming into the scene in 90’s under the guidance of a young Puff Daddy finding his way. It wasn’t until he connected with the up-and-coming producer Jermaine Dupri did Usher begin having his success with his second and third albums, My Way and 8701.

He made an impact with his fourth studio album Confessions that sold 1.1 million copies in the first week and produced four consecutive Billboard Hot 100 number one singles —"Yeah!“, "Burn”, “Confessions Part II”, and “My Boo”.  Confessions went on to sell over 20 million copies worldwide and is the last album certified diamond by a black artist.

His fifth studio album Here I Stand sold over half a million copies in the first week and spawned the number one single “Love In This Club”. In 2010, his album Raymond v. Raymond was his third consecutive number one album on the Billboard 200 and launched the nearly sold-out OMG Tour, one of the highest grossing tours of the 2010s. The album also produced his ninth Billboard Hot 100 number one single “OMG”.  With “OMG” Usher became only the fourth artist to have number one hits across three consecutive decades.

Usher has continued success into the 2010s decade with his sixth studio album Lookin' 4 Myself which produced the top 10, Grammy award-winning single “Climax”.  In 2015, his single “I Don’t Mind” reached number eleven on the Billboard Hot 100 and was his thirteenth number one hit on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-hop songs chart.  This feat was achieved with no promotion or music video, showing just how much star power Usher still holds in his hands.

He’s also received numerous awards and accolades including 18 Billboard Music Awards, 8 Grammy awards and a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

As music evolves so does Usher. He goes by the saying “Evolve or Evaporate” and that’s what he does.   Whether it’s the singles “I Don’t Mind” or “No Limit” he knows how to stay on top of the game.

Website

songs.title: Burn

description.plain:
“Burn” is a song by American R&B singer Usher, released as the second single from his album, Confessions.  Lyrically, the song is about breakup in a relationship.

“Burn” reached the top spot on various charts around the world, including the United States, United Kingdom, and New Zealand.

songs.full_title: Yeah! by Usher (Ft. Lil Jon & Ludacris)
songs.title: Yeah!

description.plain:
Lil Jon’s work ethic is legendary in the music business. All artists he’s worked with rave about his preparedness and professionalism in the studio. Nowhere are these qualities more evident than in “Yeah!”

This song became so popular in the year it was released that Usher, Lil Jon and Ludacris received an award for best collaboration song for it at an award show and Ludacris boasted that the three of them were going to make a collaboration album in response to the reception the song received. The three went on to remix Usher’s song “Red Light” and collaborated on Lil Jon and the Eastside Boyz’s song “Lovers and Friends,” which seemed like demos for the album. For unknown reasons, an album, as well as anything close to one, never came into fruition.

songs.title: Climax

description.plain: 2012, a year where pop icons like Justin Bieber and Taylor Swift married their own musical agendas to the moment’s most popular sound– DUBSTEP– Usher’s gurgling collaboration with Diplo is the master class of this modern arrangement. And unlike most other tracks mining this popular vein, Climax doesn’t rush to the genre-defining-to-the-point-of-parody drop.

songs.full_title: Confessions Part II by Usher
songs.title: Confessions Part II

description.plain: “Confessions Part II” is a song by R&B singer Usher, produced by Jermaine Dupri and Bryan-Michael Cox for Usher’s fourth album Confessions. Written by Usher, Dupri and Cox, the song is a confession of a man to his woman about his impregnated mistress, a continuation of “Confessions Part I”, which relates to a man’s infidelity. Its personal content evoked rumors and early responses from the public even before its release, believing that Usher was asserting the truth; however, Dupri divulged that the story behind the album is his and Usher explained that he only took inspiration from his friends' similar experiences.

songs.full_title: No Limit by Usher (Ft. Young Thug)
songs.title: No Limit

description.plain:
Usher and Young Thug team up for the first single, “No Limit,“ off Hard II Love. In the years leading up to this album, he talked about the city’s importance in hip-hop, and mentioning Young Thug specifically. In an interview with Billboard, he said:

From Future to Young Thug—I think Atlanta’s more relevant now than it’s ever been, musically and culturally.

The song contains numerous references to No Limit Records, the legendary New Orleans label run by Master P in the ‘90s. This is very much the era that Usher came up in, though he’s managed to stay relevant over the two decades (No Limit, on the other hand, declared bankruptcy in 2003). Master P got a chance to respond to the homage, on Hip-Hop Wired, saying:

I’m a big fan of Usher. To have an R&B artist make music about me and my career—that let me know we did something right.

Usher revealed an alternative cover, which features a photo of a sculpture of Usher that was done by friend and artist Daniel Arsham — Usher explained he had to stand still for the four hours it took to complete it.



The official music video dropped as a Tidal exclusive on August 5th, 2016.

songs.full_title: U Got It Bad by Usher
songs.title: U Got It Bad

description.plain:
Second single off of 8701, a Billboard Hot 100 chart topping R&B ballad.

Lyrically, the song’s inspired by a true story. Jermaine Dupri (co-writer and co-producer of the song) and Usher were in the studio trying to record some music for the album, but Usher was continually distracted by a girl he had brought into the studio. Following an argument, the girl left. A while later, they started talking on the phone, which prompted Dupri to kick Usher out of the studio telling him, “We’re going to do this [session] later on. You got it completely too bad right now. You got it bad.” This ignited the inspiration for the song, and once Usher had left, Dupri started writing its lyrics, with the notion that it was going to be a big hit. Once Usher had returned to the studio, Dupri shared the story of the song with him, and the rest is history…

Jermaine Dupri told Complex:

“I learned from ‘Nice & Slow’ that people wanted that. ‘Nice & Slow’ was a big record, but we only made one. We went into that album saying, we got to make another ‘Nice & Slow.’ What I did with ‘U Got It Bad’ was take it to the next level, make another version of that. ‘U Got It Bad’ was basically just another version of ‘Nice & Slow’ with me trying to repeat and just make a better version.”

songs.full_title: Rivals by Usher (Ft. Future)
songs.title: Rivals

description.plain:
Usher invites Future for some R&B bars over a soft beat. The audio and music video premiered on Tidal on August 30th.

This is the first ever official collaboration between Atlanta artists Usher & Future as the only other track they’ve both appeared on was Usher’s remix of “UOENO”.

songs.full_title: Confessions Part I by Usher
songs.title: Confessions Part I

description.plain: “Confessions Part I” is a song by R&B singer Usher, produced by Jermaine Dupri and Bryan-Michael Cox for Usher’s fourth album Confessions. Written by Usher, Dupri and Cox, the song is a confession of a man to his woman about his impregnated mistress. Its personal content evoked rumors and early responses from the public even before its release, believing that Usher was asserting the truth; however, Dupri divulged that the story behind the album is his and Usher explained that he only took inspiration from his friends' similar experiences.

songs.full_title: DJ Got Us Fallin' in Love by Usher (Ft. Pitbull)
songs.title: DJ Got Us Fallin’ in Love
songs.title_with_featured: DJ Got Us Fallin' in Love (Ft. Pitbull)

description.plain:
This song was the first single from Usher’s EP “Versus”. As a single it reached number five on Billboard’s Hot 100, which did not quite measure up to his number one hit “OMG”, that he did with will.i.am earlier that year, and was featured on his “Raymond v. Raymond” album. For Pitbull it continued a strong year as featured artist, after his performance on Enrique Iglesias' hit “I Like It” from earlier that year

The lyrics are pretty straight-forward, about the club scene as a place to unwind and let loose. Usher asks a girl if he’s seen her before, either as a tired pick-up line, or from a genuine sense of deja-vu. Pitbull chimes in with a mix of bragadaccio and sexual innuendo. There are in fact two versions of the song, one in which Pitbull’s rap contains a lot more Spanglish, perhaps intended for a Hispanic audience. This, however, is the version featured in the official video

songs.full_title: U Remind Me by Usher
songs.title: U Remind Me

description.plain:
Released in 2001, “U Remind Me” served as the lead single from Usher’s third album, 8701.

The song became a huge success both commercially and critically. As well as topping the Billboard Hot 100, it also won Usher his first Grammy Award for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance.

songs.full_title: Lemme See by Usher (Ft. Rick Ross)
songs.title: Lemme See

description.plain:
This song was the third single off Usher’s seventh album, Looking 4 Myself. It peaked at respectable number 46 on the Billboard Hot 100. The music video was released on 14th June, 2012 and has over 20 million views.

In this song, Usher is contemplating on whether he should take a certain female clubgoer home with him, it ends up with them having sexual intercourse. While Rick Ross is seducing a female with his luxurious lifestyle.

It’s not the only time the two collaborates on a track, they also made “Touch'N You” together.

songs.title: Love in This Club Part II
songs.title_with_featured: Love in This Club Part II (Ft. Beyoncé & Lil Wayne)

description.plain:
Usher was particularly excited about Wayne’s verse on the remix, as he told MTV:

Wayne, pound for pound, is one of the illest in the game, and I wanted it to be something that would be a surprise, be a shock. Have shock value. That’s what the remix is all about. ‘Damn, did you hear the remix? It’s crazier than the original. I like it more.’ I just think it’s great. Plies actually did a verse on it as well. He came with it. Everybody basically did their thing, and I am very happy that I was able to put that one in.

Check the original version out here!

songs.full_title: Crash by Usher
songs.title: Crash

description.plain:
“Crash” is the follow-up single to the Young Thug collaboration “No Limit”. Both are expected to be on Usher’s forthcoming album, titled Hard II Love. “Crash” was described as a “more radio-friendly, pop approach,” where Usher delivered a “catchy, high-pitched R&B ballad” about a past relationship.

Usher also revealed an alternative cover, similar to the one used for “No Limit”. Both are photos of a sculpture of Usher that was done by friend and artist Daniel Arsham — they explained Usher had to stand still for 4 hours for him to complete.

songs.full_title: You Make Me Wanna... by Usher
songs.title: You Make Me Wanna...

description.plain:
“You Make Me Wanna…” is the lead single from Usher’s second studio album, My Way.

In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, Usher talked about the relationship issues that led to this song’s concept:

‘I was with one girl, but I had flown to Los Angeles and I fell in love with this other girl. And what was so odd about it is she started out as a friend, and was encouraging me to keep my relationship afloat. And then I’m like, 'Well, shit, why don’t I be with you?’
